oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Using Prostaglandins to Control Reproduction Functions in Farm Animals
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Godke, Robert A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: reproduction
prostaglandin- F2α
luteolysis
luteal regression
ovulation
semen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Many general review articles have been published relating to the physiological roles that prostaglandins may have in biological systems of man and animals (see reviews by Bergstrom et al., 1968; Horton, 1969; Moghissi and Murry, 1970; Karim, 1972, Hinman, 1972; Lauderdale, 1974, Brenner, 1976; Horton, 1976; Horton and Poyser, 1976) and in recent years text and reference books have been published solely on this group of compounds. Those readers interested in reviewing the chemical nomenclature and specific physiological functions of prostaglandins in farm animals are referred to several excellent reviews (Inskeep, 1973; Downey, 1974; Hansel et al.., 1976; Stabenfeldt et al., 1978). Practical application of this group of unique compounds for controllong reproductive function in animals began when Pharris and Wyngarden (1969) were first to report that prostaglandins have luteolytic properties in laboratory rats. Since the early studies of induced luteolysis in hysterectomized pseudo-pregnant and pregnant laboratory animals and in intact monkeys (Kirton et al., 1970), prostaglandin- F2α has been reported to cause premature luteal tissue regression and decline in circulating progesterone in the cycling ewe (McCracken et al., 1970; McCracken, 1971; McCracken et al., 1972; Chamley et al., 1972), the mare (Noden et al., 1974; Oxender et al., 1974; Kreider et al., 1975) as well as in the cow (Louis et al., 1972a; Louis et al., 1973; Henricks et al., 1974). Although attempts have been made, PGF2α has not been successful for induction of complete luteal regression in the cycling gilt (Diehl and Day, 1974; Hallford et al., 1975). The following sections of this review will cover those areas of reproduction in farm animals where PGF2α and its analogues are involved with or related to reproductive organs, ovulation control (luteal regression), superovulation, embryo transplantation, abortifacient capabilities, induced parturition, postpartum interval, abnormal ovarian structures and uterine pathology. Also, their effects on semen and possible implications of prostaglandins on male reproduction will be discussed.
